    Question again proposed,

    "That the sum of $31,522,760 for Head 49 stand part of the Schedule."

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): Mr Chairman, Sir, I am ready to answer the request made by the Member for Paya Lebar (Mr Lim Koon Teck) in his motion yesterday. He intimated to me after the adjournment that he would like a little more information about the tuberculosis scheme which we intend to carry out in our Ministry. It is intended that all known cases of tuberculosis be followed up so that we can be sure that they are obtaining adequate treatment either as in-patients or as out-patients. As soon as such an organisation which I explained yesterday has been established, then it is worth while intensifying in Singapore our case findings. Effective tuberculosis control is likely to be an expensive undertaking, and for this reason it is most important that we should have a clearly defined estimate of the extent of the problem which faces us, and this is where Australian assistance comes in. We have asked for a team of experts with equipment for mass miniature radiography to undertake a short-term survey to cover about 50,000 persons. Subject to further consultation with the Australian experts, it is proposed to select three sample areas in Singapore - two in the city area and one in the rural area. Such a survey of complete groups to a total of 50,000 persons will take at least six months and the results will give us a very much clearer knowledge of the real incidence of tuberculosis in a densely populated and less densely populated area. When this intensive survey is over, the Australian experts will withdraw, leaving their equipment for our future use. Thereafter we shall continue with the case-finding programme, inevitably at a much slower pace but as quickly as available staff and funds will permit. There is no intention to nationalise tuberculosis. We shall welcome and need all the help we

Column: 980

can get from S.A.T.A. and from private practitioners, and there is no intention to dictate or interfere with treatment being given by non-government practitioners. We wish only to ensure that if a person has tuberculosis, he is given treatment and to ensure also, if he is infective, that the public are adequately safeguarded from his spreading the infection.

    It is interesting to note that a study group on tuberculosis control sponsored by the World Health Organisation met at the end of November 1955. The technical report of their findings has just been published. In that study group were represented experts from ten countries, and in their report they stated, inter alia, that "The establishment in each country of a Central Tuberculosis Register covering notified and re-notified cases will be of great value for the study of the epidemiology of the disease." and that "Complete pulmonary examinations of sample groups are necessary to obtain a reliable index for the prevalence of tuberculosis." It is also interesting to note that their recommendations represent, in fact, the programme which we have now formulated in Singapore. I think, Mr Chairman, I have covered all the points which the Member for Paya Lebar wishes to know.

    Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim (Sembawang): Mr Chairman, Sir, I look at page 227, sub-head 1 (4) and I see there the post of Assistant Director of Medical Services. Previously this title was the Chief Medical Officer, General Hospital. The job is still the same, that is, that the Chief Medical Officer of the General Hospital looks after all the hospitals in Singapore. Sir, the Government has created a new post called "Medical Superintendent". You can see this at page 247, sub-head 68 (1) . What is the idea of having this new appointment, Sir, when the work of the Chief Medical Officer, General Hospital, is to look after all the hospitals in Singapore? I see no reason why there should be a Medical Superintendent to take over part of the duties of the former Chief Medical Officer, General Hospital. I hope the Minister can explain this.

    Mr Braga: Mr Chairman, the Member for Sembawang was probably not in the House yesterday or he was not paying attention, but I gave a very full explanation of the reasons why, owing to the fantastic amount of work, we have found it necessary to have a full-time Medical Officer in charge of the General Hospital and a full-time Administrative Officer to co-operate the work of all the hospitals.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Chairman, Sir, may I seek one point of information from the Minister? Will the persons to be X-rayed in the sampling of the three areas to which mention was made be selected, or will they be asked to come forward on a voluntary basis, or how will the sampling be done?

    Mr Braga: I think the Member for Tanglin is fully conversant with the arrangements that have been made. I would only remind him of the conference which he and Mr Garlick of S.A.T.A. had in my Ministry. It is, in fact, our intention to give free X-rays on miniature radiography in these three areas. Option will be given to the people in these areas to be either X-rayed by us or by S.A.T.A. X-rays will be on a voluntary basis.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Chairman, I am sorry the Minister has not understood my question. I was not referring to any conference which has taken place. That point was not made clear to me at that time. What I want to know is: I think there are going to be three areas in which about 15,000 people are going to be X-rayed. Now is that going to be done on a voluntary basis as far as the persons who are going to be X-rayed are concerned? Are they going to be invited to come forward, and is it going to be done through propaganda; or have they got to be X-rayed; or how is it going to be done?

    Mr Braga: Yes, we hope to do it successfully on a voluntary basis.

    Head 50-

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Chairman, Sir, I move,

Column: 982



    To reduce by $29,990 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 1 (1) , Minister, on page 269 of the Estimates.

    Sir, in moving this amendment, I hope that it will not be construed that I am trying to take away the salary of the Minister. The Minister for Labour and Welfare is also concurrently the Chief Minister, and as the salary of the Chief Minister is far higher than that of the Minister for Labour and Welfare, I am sure that he prefers to draw the salary of the Chief Minister rather than that of the Minister for Labour and Welfare.

    I would refer you, Sir, to page 161, the "Remarks" column against subhead 1 (1) which says:

    "No provision entered for 1956 as the Chief Minister then was also Minister for Commerce and Industry."

Sir, the Member for Cairnhill then was Chief Minister and concurrently Minister for Commerce and Industry.

    Sir, in this case, as the Budget shows a deficit, I do not think it is fair to put the figure of $30,000, shown against sub-head 1 (1) , Minister, on page 269, in the Estimates because it will misguide us. However, rather than take away that vote altogether, I would much prefer to put in a token vote of $10 in its place, because the Assistant Minister for Labour and Welfare may be promoted to the post of Minister if there is a vacancy in due course. If that happens, we can, without any difficulty, re-insert the figure of $30,000 against the post of Minister. Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy(Telok Ayer): Mr Chairman, Sir, the Chief Minister has been good enough to take over the portfolio of the Minister for Labour and Welfare. This has saved the Colony a lot of money - a Minister's salary, allowance, entertainment expenses, etc. The former Chief Minister, the Member for Cairnhill, also did the same thing in the beginning when he held the portfolio of Commerce and Industry. His was a difficult task when he began to work the new Constitution. I remember his words at, I think, the first Assembly

Column: 983

sitting - that there was not even an ink-pot or a sheet of note-paper, or even an office for the Chief Minister. I also remember that he had to try and wrest power from the ex-officios. I also remember that he had to put up a fight with the Colonial Office. The first Chief Minister's task was difficult, with the result that he had to give up later on the portfolio of the Minister for Commerce and Industry. But now things are well under way, and we are grateful to the present Chief Minister for taking up both this portfolio and that of the Minister for Labour and Welfare, thereby saving the revenue of the Colony. He might be able to give us information why this post of Minister for Labour and Welfare is kept open. The fact is that he has to go to London, and his is a minority Government. I wonder whether other parties will co-operate with him when he goes to London, or whether the Colonial Office will accept what a minority Government says. Sir, I believe there is something in the minds of the present Coalition Government or in that of the Chief Minister, and I would like to hear why this post of Minister of Labour and Welfare is kept open. If the vote is reduced to a token $10, he will still have the same chance, but it is no use carrying such a big item in the Budget. Sir, I would like to have an explanation from the Chief Minister.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Chairman, Sir, the Member for Queenstown has rightly said that I am not drawing salaries from two Ministries. The reason why this vote remains in the Estimates is because I am not so sure what is going to transpire in February. As hon. Members know, if this time we go again and we do not succeed in our mission, Singapore will have to find a new Minister for Labour and Welfare.

    The Member for Queenstown also referred to the Member for Cairnhill when he was the Chief Minister and at the same time Minister for Commerce and Industry. In his case, Sir, I would like to point out to the Assembly that, under the then Rendel Constitution, the Chief Minister had to hold a portfolio.

Column: 984

So he became the Minister for Commerce and Industry, who is also the chief of all the other Ministers. But as a result of his talks with the Secretary of State last December, his Government was able to get a concession, that, in view of the heavy responsibilities of the Chief Minister, he should not be loaded with another Ministry. His Ministry of Commerce and Industry was therefore separated from him and so the portfolio of Minister for Commerce and Industry was created. Now when I accepted the Chief Ministership, I said that my spiritual home was in the Labour Ministry, and it still is. I will not give that up. But one must not forget that although I may not want to do it, I might be forced to do it, may be in February when I come back from London. Or I might be forced to do it earlier, may be on account of reasons of health. But I can say that, as long as there is life in me, and as long as I am allowed to hold it, I will hold it. But the amendment proposed by the Member for Queenstown, Sir, means nothing. The vote is still there. What the hon. Member wants is to see a reduction of a comparatively few dollars in the Estimates. It is just $29,990 - it is nothing in an Estimate of millions upon millions of dollars. Sir, we cannot accept the amendment on this side because of the uncertainty of the situation.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Sir, I think this side of the House should be satisfied with the explanation given. The position, of course, appears to be very uncertain, as the Chief Minister has pointed out, and I think we should remain contented for the time being.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Chairman, Sir, I do fully appreciate what the Chief Minister has in mind where his appointment is concerned, that someone should be there, whether he himself or the Assistant Minister if and when he is promoted. But the fact is that in my amendment I am not trying to take away the vote altogether. Where a token vote is concerned, if it is passed, it gives authority for the money to be spent. But if a token vote is taken away altogether, then authority has to

Column: 985

be sought for. And when the Chief Minister appoints a new Minister for Labour and Welfare or appoints a new Minister, he may have got to go to the Governor in Council or Council of Ministers to seek approval for that appointment. I feel, Sir, that where an estimate is concerned, I would prefer a token vote rather than an imaginative figure. When such time as the appointment has actually been filled, we could then easily release that token vote where the actual amount is concerned. But since the Member for Telok Ayer has said that he is prepared to overlook it, and in order to save time, may I have your permission and that of hon. Members to withdraw my amendment?

    The Chairman: Is it the pleasure of the Committee, then, that this amendment should be withdrawn?

    Hon. Members: Yes.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Head 51-

    Question proposed,

    "That the sum of $1,102,330 for Head 51 stand part of the Schedule."

    Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim: Mr Chairman, Sir, on page 270, sub-head 1 (5) , "Deputy Assistant Controllers of Immigration, 29," - may the Minister inform us what is, first, the vacancy position at the moment; second, how many of the 29 appointments have been filled?

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Chairman, Sir, I must have notice of that question.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Chairman, Sir, the question of immigration is causing grave concern amongst the Chinese population in Singapore. As a matter of fact, it is more of a puzzle, because the man in the street is not fully aware of the actual functions of this Department or what is the system of application for entry into this country. Sir, I have known of cases where applications for entry for wives or aged parents met with great difficulty as compared to the ease with which strip-

Column: 986

teasers and singers can enter this colony. It is, of course, a fact that these stripteasers and singers come here for a very short period, say, six months or so.

    Another surprise is that the application for extension of the visas of these entertainers meets with no difficulty. I have known of cases where singers in night-clubs have been here for more than three years. I wonder how they manage this - may be they are females! I think that is why the immigration authorities take such a lenient view! But I have known of cases where technicians have found much difficulty in applying for entry visas for even a short stay here. I have known of a permanent wave expert - a man, in this instance! - who was quite prepared to come down to Singapore and give the benefit of his knowledge and experience to our local people. He has tried, but without success, to get an entry visa. If the Minister for Labour and Welfare desires it, I can one day bring this case to him.

    Sir, our Chinese custom is that we prefer to have our wives and aged parents stay with us as a family unit rather than that they live apart from us. Where immigration is concerned, there is a proviso that a marriage photograph must be produced. Sir, in olden times, there was no question of a marriage photograph because the man and his wife were too shy of each other and more so of exposing themselves to the public. I think this proviso should be relaxed in such cases. There are also cases of aged parents wishing to come to Singapore to join their sons or daughters, but the reply from the Immigration Department is always the same - they are not within the category to be considered. I wonder what are the categories to be considered, Sir, because it is very difficult to say the actual categories. Now a son may have a well-established business here and is able to maintain his parents, but they are not staying with him, and it will naturally be a cause of much sorrow to them all if they are kept apart, instead of living together as a happy family. This son,

Column: 987

Sir, who is a business man, is also prepared to give a guarantee to the Government that his parents, if they are allowed to enter the colony, would not be a burden to the State. There are cases, Sir, where the applicants have estates and certainly in their position they are in a position to maintain their parents. I hope that the Government will be prepared to let the public know what are the categories which they consider immigrants should come into before they are allowed to enter here, because as far as I know, it is only the wives who are considered and they are only subject to the production of documents of family photographs. But what about aged parents? I may get a reply from the Minister that above the age of 60 -

    Mr D. S. Marshall (Cairnhill): Hundreds are coming in.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: I do agree with that. Even thousands are coming in! It really surprises me, Sir, that in some cases they are considered and in other cases they are not. What is the difference then? I can tell you, Sir, that although the age of entry for children is 12, I have known of children 15 or 16 years old coming into this colony. How did they manage it? I wonder if the Minister for Labour and Welfare, who is in charge of the Immigration Department, can explain this. At one time I went into a shop and I was surprised to see a boy of this height [Indicating.] who told me that he came from China only a few days previously and I asked him how old he was and how he came into the colony. To my surprise he replied that his age, by Chinese reckoning, was 16. To account for the difference between 16 and 12 years of age is beyond me. Is it not surprising then how a boy of 16 was allowed to come in? As I have said earlier, it is a puzzle - in some cases, they are allowed in and in other cases they are not. I think there should be a change of system in the Immigration Department. I wonder whether the Minister for Labour and Welfare could institute an investigation into the functions of that

Column: 988

Department so that there will be no more discrimination.

    I may also point out in the Member for Cairnhill that it is not hundreds or even thousands of aged parents who have come in. Millions of wives, I should say, have come in through some way or other! So I do hope that the Minister could set up a committee to investigate into the workings of that Department.

    The Minister for Labour and Welfare (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Chairman, Sir, as the Minister for Labour and Welfare but not drawing the salary of the Minister for Labour and Welfare, may I now attempt to justify or give an answer to the attack on the Immigration Department? The Member for Queenstown seems to be concerned with the immigration policy. He asks for information, which he could easily get from the Immigration Ordinance, of the categories of people who are permitted entry into the colony. Sir, before I became Minister for Labour and Welfare, I had been toiling and toiling for the people of Singapore in so far as their immigration problems were concerned. This was ever since 1948, and so if I claim to know a lot about that Department, I hope hon. Members will understand that it is a claim based on personal knowledge.

    The hon. Member says that marriage photographs are insisted before entry is permitted. I think his information is incorrect. A marriage photograph is not insisted upon. It was insisted upon in 1948, 1949, 1950, 1951 I think, 1952 maybe, so much so that if a marriage photograph is asked for and if the sponsor of the immigrant has it, it will help to substantiate his application for entry; but if there is no marriage photograph, it does not mean that his case is that much weaker. I would say that it was because of the insistence of marriage photographs that photographers in Singapore made a lot of money by imposing one photograph upon another, so much so that when the sponsor (meaning the husband or the wife; the applicant is the person who desires entry) was asked, "Why did you forge this photograph?", he replied, "I do not know. I

Column: 989

was told that I must produce a marriage photograph and so I produce a marriage photograph!" It was because of that that the production of a marriage photograph is no longer insisted upon. If the sponsor can produce one, it will help his case; but if he cannot, well, that is that.

    The Chairman: Order. The time has expired.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Head 52-

    Question proposed,

    "That the sum of $1,024,280 for Head 52 stand part of the Schedule."

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Chairman, Sir, I think it is a wellknown fact that labour is the economic backbone of this colony and it also plays a vital role in the stability of this country. Without labour, industry would not be able to progress. Government, I believe, is trying to see that there is less unemployment. It is trying its best to ensure that there is no unemployment in this colony, and that is why a labour exchange has been created. But, Sir, in my opinion, the system of operation in that labour exchange is rather unsatisfactory. I have known cases where long queues have stood alongside the Havelock Road building waiting either to be registered or sent to employers or firms which require labour. The coordination between the employers and the labour exchange is not very satisfactory. There may be cases of a firm which requires a large number of carpenters but the labour exchange is unable to supply them; whereas, in fact, there are thousands of unemployed carpenters who are not prepared to register or have not registered themselves at the labour exchange. So this is the reason why I say the system is not satisfactory. It is either the employers or the unemployed who are not making much use of the labour exchange. I presume they do not know the benefits to be derived from the use of that exchange. Or it may be that the staff there is inadequate so that they are unable to set up a new system whereby the employers, the unemployed and the exchange could have co-ordination.

Column: 990

The answer to this problem, if I may say so again, is to appoint a committee to go into the functions of the labour exchange with a view to making recommendations for improvement.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, it is again the Member for Queenstown who speaks and the Minister for Labour who labours for no reward! Sir, he brought up the question of the work of the labour exchange. I agree that the work of the labour exchange is not as satisfactory as I should have liked to see, but I am sure he himself realises the limitations under which the labour exchange has to work.

    In the first place, there is no compulsion on employers to seek to fill vacancies through the labour exchange. In the second place, there are a number of private employment agencies, about whom I have already asked for more information, who appear to be able to do better business in this particular line. It has been reported to me, Sir, that more and more people would like to make use of these agencies because, through their own organisations within the offices, they are able to know in advance of any vacancy that may arise in any particular office. In some cases, it has been reported to the Labour Department that there have been a good number of illegal practices going on in these so-called private employment agencies and I have therefore, as I have said earlier, asked for further information about them.

    The Member for Queenstown asked for a committee to be set up to look into and improve upon the work of the labour exchange. I would like to inform him, Sir, that there is already a small committee on the job and I hope they will be able to make recommendations to me which will improve the working of the labour exchange.

    In regard to the long queues of people waiting at the labour exchange for registration, perhaps the Member for Queenstown has confused them with the long queues waiting for relief at the Social Welfare Department. The labour exchange and the Social Welfare Department are on the same floor, Sir, and the queues could have been enlarged because there is only one entrance.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Chairman, Sir, I am glad that the Minister is calling for a report on the working of these private employment agencies. I think the Government should take very strong action against them. To my knowledge, these agencies are, in fact, exploiting the workers rather than assisting them. A registration fee is levied whether you get employment or not; and as soon as employment is found for persons who have registered with them, a certain percentage of the first month's salary has to be paid to them.     Head 53-

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Chairman, Sir, I move,

    To reduce by $10 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 1 (46) , Community Centre Organisers, on page 281 of the Estimates.

    Sir, in moving this amendment, I must draw the attention of the House to the fact that Community Centre Organisers are new innovations in this Budget. They have been here for only a few years. May I suggest to the House, Sir, that this type of employment is not necessary? It gives me a queer feeling to have that title "Community Centre Organisers" put into the Budget. It gives me the idea that people in Singapore must be organised. It gives me the feeling that people cannot organise themselves before; but, Sir, nothing is further from the truth. In fact, people have always organised themselves and will organise themselves when they want to. But they will not want to organise themselves if

Column: 992

they are forced into it. Sir, we find that in every locality in Singapore little associations have come up. We have little guilds coming up. People have formed themselves into sports associations, benevolent associations, clan associations and associations to promote a certain type of welfare activity or social activity; and in all such cases they have never had any prompting from anybody. In fact, it is the interest in these people which causes them to band themselves into whatever organisations they want. Now it may be said by the Department concerned that this can only apply to many decades ago, say, before the second world war, when everybody was staying in a fixed place for a very long time; but after the war, we have the growth of new estates and the coming of this event has brought people from all parts of Singapore to stay together. Then, of course, there will be problems which are common to them and which they want to solve, but because of the shortness of time, they are not able to come together; so we must have somebody to look after such things for them. But, Sir, I say this is not true. In this case of new estates, where the people have common problems, they usually organise themselves into community centres to fight their own battle. They need no urging from the Department concerned.

    Sir, let us now look at the work of these community centre organisers during the past few years. I happen to be pretty familiar with the work which they are doing and in most cases I think they have nothing much to recommend themselves for the maintenance of their jobs. A community centre is built in a place which is not conspicuous enough to attract attention and in such a way that people will find it quite inconvenient to make use of it. In such centres there will be a few types of activities - boys' club activities, girls' club activities - and there will be a little library in the corner and occasionally the members will meet there for a lecture or a short talk. But invariably, Sir, these centres are empty - empty for the most part of the month, for the most part of the week, and for the most part of the

Column: 993

day. You can say, "Yes, we have a centre and it is catering for the needs of the young children. We run classes." Yes, these centres run classes, but classes for about 20 or 30 or 40 people and no more; and if you can call them community centres, when they are being made use of by only a very small number of people, then I wonder if there is not something wrong with the title. However, even if we confine ourselves to the subject of the centre being made use of by these young people, let us see how the work is being done. Sometimes an association will come in and ask for the use of the place, and in one case that I know of, the organiser said, "You will have to write in officially." I quite agree, Sir, that community centres deal with all sorts of people, and such people will also include those who are illiterate, and to ask illiterate people to write in officially is, I think, the height of folly. Or you may have an organisation asking, "You are not going to use this place for a few days. Let us have it for the purposes of weight-lifting." This organisation is prepared to guarantee that the building will not be spoiled, the floor will not be chipped, and should there be damage, the association is prepared to compensate for such damage. But even then the association is not allowed to make use of that centre. A community centre, according to that type of organiser, should be kept as a white elephant, white-washed and cleanly swept, nobody making use of it because it will then not be dirty.

    Let me point out another fact. Invariably we find that organisers are sent into a community about which they know nothing. I put it to you, Sir, that if you are sent in to organise a certain community - in fact, they do not need your assistance at all - then the very least that you must know is that you should know the people and the conditions there. If you do not, then you can do no work at all. In fact, the work that has been done has nothing to recommend itself. I have known of one centre where, instead of the organisers making everybody happy to go into it and drink coffee, talk together, read the papers, discuss the day's work, these people have divided them into factions.
